Award.AwardTitle: Intelligent Recommendation of NSDL Resources to support Middle School Teacher Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Development is underway of intelligent resource management and collaboration tools to increase the use of NSDL resources by middle school teachers of mathematics and science within the Middle School Portal 2: Math and Science Pathways (MSP2). MSP2 is a social networking site that promotes collaboration among teachers. The project builds on prior projects on automatic document classification, forum participant profiling and connecting help seekers to peer mentors within online forums. The add-on tool processes content posted by individual teachers according to their activities and interests and recommends use of matching NSDL resources. The automatic analysis of online forum content enable reuses of content that is difficult to access currently. The potential for wide adoption of the technology in any pathway portal is present. Such adoption is likely to entice more users to a portal because of the value-added recommender services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PedConnect project set out to improve online community resources for educators by developing and deploying recommendation tools that connected educators with better online resources, both in terms of content and connections to colleagues around the country.  

Social networking sites for teachers facilitate teacher communication and information sharing.   For example, The Middle School Portal 2 (MSP2) is a social networking site for middle school math and science teachers. Such sites can help teachers maintain professional support and integrate new digital teaching methods and materials, without costly workshops and professional development courses.  The PedConnect project developed intelligent resource evaluation and management tools that characterize different types of online resources available for middle school math and science teachers.

Building on several prior NSF projects on automatic online discussion classification, forum participant profiling, and modeling teacher social networking, the project used social networking activities and user models to assess the quality of the resources used or discussed by the users. The resource assessment results were then used to suggest resources that met individual needs, promoting use of high quality resources.

The project developed innovative technologies for automatic educational resource classification and assessment, and validation of the assessments with educational material experts and experienced teachers.  The results of the project create a broad social impact by enhancing access and use of high quality resources within a nationwide teacher networking site. This research has the potential to transform middle school teaching practices by providing instructors with easier access of useful resources and effective assistance from social networking sites.
